course.subject: COMP
course.name: Competitive Programming in Cybersecurity II
course.description: The course will be offered as an 2-credit course in the Spring semester. Students who have passed COMP4901N and have gotten the instructor consent can join COMP4901O in a subsequent Spring semester, they will be working together based on the knowledge they have learned from COMP4901O, forming teams to further investigate various advanced topics related to the more practical side of cybersecurity. They will then join the various cybersecurity contests. The students will get 2 credits for successfully completing COMP4901O. Contest-type “attack and defend” programming problems (also known as Capture-The-Flag, CTF, problems) will be employed throughout this course to practically train the students for the cybersecurity contests. The topics covered will include but not limited to binary analysis, cryptography, web exploitations, and packet capture analysis. These topics will be covered in the practical attack-and-defend context. Recent developments in the topics will also be investigated by students via CTF problem solving. Instructor's approval is required.

reviews.author: Starry Miracle
reviews.title: Should reg COMP4901O if you are invited to join
reviews.comment_content:
Extension of COMP4901N. May differ each semester so only for reference.

Topics
│
├─Week 1
│  ├─Course introduction
│  └─Hello PWN world
│
├─Week 3
│  ├─The Docker program for containers
│  └─Write up sharing(by 4901O students)
│       ├─1. Super Encryption
│       ├─2. Proprietary Protocol
│       └─3. Mind Seeker
│
├─Week 4 (Guest Talk)
│  └─Introduction to Red Teaming - by Charleston Lee
│
├─Week 5
│  └─Reverse Anrdoid Application
│
└─Week 6
   └─Algebra In Cryptography

Student Presentations
│
├─Week 8
│  ├─JavaScript Prototype Pollution
│  └─Hardware Side Channels
│
├─Week 9
│  └─Elliptic Curve Cryptography
│
├─Week 10
│  ├─Heap Exploitation
│  ├─House of Spirit
│  └─Common knowledge, attacks and weaknesses in Crypto implementations
│
├─Week 11
│  ├─NoSQL Injections
│  └─Two Reversing Writeups
│
├─Week 12
│  ├─House of Force
│  └─Bleichenbacher & Manger attacks
│
└─Week 13
    ├─Quantum Computation and Cryptography
    ├─More on XSS and Cookies
    └─Memory Forensics

(利申: Format copied from https://ust.space/review/COMP4901N/view/Chod3MFPcUKkwtsjrqcK2Ux9on5sJm16)
reviews.comment_teaching:
It depends. If you are a local student then you can probably understand both Hong Kong (strange) accent and normal foreigner tone. If you are a foreign student the you may have slight difficulty in listening to local presenters.

Half of the course will be presentation by expert CTF team members.
Another half of the course you are teaching each other.

(Quote from course introduction: senior students who have taken part in Cybersecurity contests will conduct the training or sharing sessions
in the course)

For more information, please refer to COMP4901N review.
reviews.comment_grading:
wow I got my first A+ in UST from this course

===== From course website =====
Class attendance + participation in at least 2 CTFs : 35%
Peer-reviewed presentation/writeups : 50%
Submitting peer review comments on time : 15%
Bonus for additional CTF writeups : 30% (on the top of the previous 100%)
reviews.comment_workload:
Super light workload, learn while having fun

I have finished most of the workload in the first half of the semester.

No final exam/mid-term, what a good course!!!
"Fun course" -- Alex 認證

Course work:
1. 1x Presentation
2. Peer evaluation on other's presentation
3. Play 2 out of 3 CTFs and prove your existence in this course
(4. CTF writeup presentation for extra score)

reviews.author: TrebledJ
reviews.title: Presentations will be the death of me
reviews.comment_content:
There are two major components in this course: CTFs and presentations.

CTFs are the fun part. You can think of them as fun little assignments. This year, our entire class of 15 participated as one team (Firebird) across four CTFs. I'd say we did fairly well.

Onto presentations. In the first half of the course, expect lectures from seniors/experts which cover more advanced topics of cybersecurity and mindset. In the second half, expect classmates to wow you with their quickly-gained expertise or incompetence regarding one cybersecurity topic (which you get to choose, first-come first-serve).

The topics we covered were:
- Advanced Pwn
   - Linux Kernel Pwn
   - ret2dl_resolve
   - House of Force
   - FSOP
   - DNS Rebinding
- Advanced Reverse
   - Advanced Angr
- Advanced Web
   - Expression Language Injection
   - GraphQL
   - Request Smuggling
   - JS Prototype Pollution
   - NoSQL Injection
- Advanced Crypto
   - Lattice-based Attacks
   - Post-quantum Crypto
- Misc.
   - Windows/Azure AD Attack
   - Advanced OSINT
   - Sandbox Escape
reviews.comment_teaching:
A combination of lectures from seniors, professionals, researchers, and classmates.

Lectures from classmates were generally okay.

Alex really likes to talk.
reviews.comment_grading:
Did you attend all lectures and participate in at least 2 CTFs and find at least one flag in each?  (Sanity check/survey flags count.) (35%)
Did you submit your peer reviews? (15%)
Did you present coherently and was your presentation well-received (by peers and instructors)? (50%)

Then congrats, you have absolutely nothing to worry about. In fact, you're well on your way to an A+.

Bonus:
Did you submit writeups?

Unlike COMP4901N (now COMP2633), COMP4901O gives 2 credits, so there is stuff at stake.
reviews.comment_workload:
Personally this course was more taxing than COMP4901N (COMP2633), but that was simply because I threw a lot of (too much?) time into the CTFs and presentation. Most CTFs start in a Western timezone, so if you want to be the first to find a flag, you'll need to scramble against your peers... in the ungodly hour of 2am HKT.

Otherwise, it's pretty fun as well. I found it enjoyable to hunt with others for flags. There'll be multiple CTFs to participate in as well, so don't panic if you can't join all.

Presenting was annoying but turned out to also be fun and chill once I decided to place a meme on every other slide.
